Tower Dominion is a captivating tower defense strategy game that challenges players to protect their kingdom from invading forces. The Game offers a unique blend of tower building, resource management, and intense battles.

The core gameplay revolves around constructing a variety of defensive towers along the paths of enemy advancement. Players must strategically place and upgrade these towers to create an impenetrable fortification. The tower selection is diverse, ranging from basic arrow towers to devastating magical cannons, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.

As players progress, they can unlock new tower types, enhance their existing structures, and even research powerful spells to turn the tide of battle. This depth of customization allows for a high degree of replayability.

The game's visuals are a delightful mix of vibrant fantasy aesthetics and smooth, responsive animations.The game's difficulty curve is well-paced, gradually introducing new enemy types and challenges to keep players on their tip toes. Steam Achievements are also well implemented and are fun to obtain.

Overall, Tower Dominion is a must-play for fans of the tower defense genre.

TLDR: Tower dominion is a very solid tower defense game with roguelike elements.
It's one of the best games in the tower defense genre, I highly recommend it.
Some of your losses will feel really unfair, so you have to be able to handle that.
I have had zero crashes and performance is good on mid-range or higher hardware, details at the end.

# UI
Overall the UI never gets in your way and works well.
I have some nitpicks, but none of them really take away from the game.
* the game always sets the difficulty to frontier, even if you never play that difficulty
* mouse wheel scrolls too fast in codex and skips the only real important part (buildings)
* viewing the characteristics of a building from anywhere it matters takes way too many clicks

# gameplay
The game is run based and with experience you can complete a successful run in 20-30 mins.
Upgrades work based on a an RNG card based system, so you have to adapt to the choices the game gives you.
It is very similar to rogue tower, I will give a comparison later.

# RNG
Most negative reviews on this game complain about balance and RNG.
I originally felt that it is all RNG based, but after playing it more I feel like I just needed to learn.
The game has plenty of depth and there is some stuff you have to learn that's not obvious.
I do think the game has balance issues most importantly the red faction being way harder to play than the others.
The game gives you plenty of tools to win reliably with the other two factions on difficulty IV.
You can make the game as hard as you want in frontier mode, which is basically a challenge mode.
So if your ego can't handle losing and your ego requires you to play at the highest difficulty,
maybe this game is not for you.

# balance
One major balance issue that is totally legit and should be fixed is how the game spawns enemies.
The game argues that enemies are equally distributed over all entry points.
What this means is that they are equally distrubuted numerically.
So all the most powerful enemies might spawn right next to your base and the rest everywhere else.
The path the enemies walk is distributed over the number of branches the path has.
So you can split them up by having branching paths with loops in them.
Most of them seem to choose the same path though and which path they choose changes per wave.
So depending on RNG all the tanks might take the long way, or they might head straight for the base.
This is a poor implementation.

# unlocks / achievements
The achievements for this game are uninspired and easy to get.
Unlocking the doctrines in the codex is a total pain though and the how is not clearly communicated.
It doesn't really matter much, since the harder it is to unlock the less valuable it is in a run.
Some expertise doctrines require such tight RNG to get that they are basically worthless (except for endless).

# performance
I tested the game on my i7-12650H / nvidia 3050 laptop gpu and it runs,
but suffers serious fps dips (less than 10) at various points.
My AMD 7600 Ryzen 5 / AMD RX 7800 XT runs the game perfectly fluid.
It rarely drops under 60 fps and is usually above 120 fps.
In endless mode the performance tanks and in a way that suggest an optimization issue.
The framerate tanks even when idle between waves and the game should be doing almost nothing.

compared to rogue tower
+ looks better
+ far better UI
+ speed controls, yay!
+ better balanced than rogue tower IMO
+ you get to pick which sections to use to upgrade the path

- no tower priorities; lack of control on tower targetting
- rogue tower runs better on low end hardware.
- rogue tower doesn't have massive frame rate dips in endless mode

Overall I would recommend choosing this game over rogue tower if your hardware is up to snuf.

Tower Dominion is a brilliant take on the tower defense genre that blends clever strategic planning with satisfying progression. If you enjoy games that require you to constantly adapt and solve spatial puzzles, you absolutely need to check this one out. Itâ€™s been an absolute blast and a huge time sink for all the right reasons.

The core of the game is its tile-placing mechanic, which feels fantastic. Unlike traditional tower defense games where you're stuck to fixed paths, here you're actively shaping the maze and optimizing tower efficiency on the fly. Every tile placement feels meaningful, creating a dynamic puzzle where perfect synergy between your build order and the creep pathing is the key to survival.

The three distinct factions are the lifeblood of its replayability. They aren't just cosmetic swaps; each faction completely alters your strategic approach, offering different tower types, unique resource management, and playstyles. Mastering one faction is a great challenge, but learning how to effectively counter different maps and creep waves with all three provides dozens of hours of strategic depth.

Speaking of counters, the variety of creeps ensures you can never settle into a single meta build. You have to constantly react to armor types, speed bonuses, evasion units, and flying swarms, forcing you to utilize the full range of your arsenal. This reactive tactical layer is immensely rewarding when you successfully dismantle a seemingly impossible wave.

Finally, the unlocking and progression of new abilities gives you that perfect sense of growing power. The progression system feels earned, steadily introducing powerful tools and upgrades that significantly impact your strategy and allow for fun, experimental builds.

Tower Dominion is deep, challenging, and wonderfully crafted. It successfully elevates the tile-placing mechanic into a strategic necessity, making every session feel fresh and demanding. Highly recommended for fans of strategic defense and puzzle-solving!

Sadly I have to recommend no on this one as it is now. The game is cool, lots of characters and cool towers and stuff. But there's some weird balancing issues... I've had a few runs in a row now where I get to level 29 or 30 with no problem, not a single enemy damaging my command center. And then die within seconds on level 31. Feels like the enemy scaling is off, going from crushing it to getting completely destroyed the very next one is very demoralizing and frustrating, especially after having played through to the very last levels.

This game has excellent content. The production value is high, the art is lovely, and the concepts are pretty interesting. I enjoyed it.

So why can't I recommend it? Well, it's extremely poorly balanced, and gets worse the higher you go with it. Insert queue of fedora-tipping non-neurotypical keyboard warriors to rush in and defend the game with their "trololololol u just suk git gud".

It's true, though. Having played it, there are frustrating jumps in difficulty at a variety of points, variable depending on the difficulty you've set. In fairness, they've added a number of modifiers to the game, and one of them specifically scales things based on the number of single paths to the fortress. Realistically, it's not enough for the average player, and the modifiers aren't communicated particularly well.

In fact, a lot of things aren't communicated well, and it seems like that's actually a design choice. For example, they do have a setting to show tower stats- it's off by default. More than that, when it's on, you need to hover over specific weapons on a tower in order to see what's going on with the stats, and even then, it doesn't feel particularly easy to read or understand, and it's difficult to know exactly how the modifiers are playing out.

The balance, though, feels way off. One second you're doing fine, and the next, the escalation has become so severe that you simply get crushed. And not "Ah man, I let a few through", I mean going from leaking a couple, to leaking dozens.

It lacks a lot of polish and features from the genre, and that makes it difficult to make decisions. For example, you begin to really notice the lack of a way to track the enemies numbers and types when you're struggling to cover multiple points of entry. To make that worse, you don't know how that's going to do. One minute, you're building a side that's threatening to overrun you- the next, suddenly you get very little traffic on that side, and the side you were neglecting to build up because you couldn't afford to, suddenly gets massive waves.

The more you play and the higher your difficulty, the more it narrows your strategies that are realistically available. Most of the choices you get in the game don't really feel like choices, because there are clear winners. (This isn't always the case, but it is a lot of the time, for a lot of your choices).

I did check out a couple guides that were trying to teach people things they were missing when they decided the game was too hard- very disappointed. They didn't teach anything out of the ordinary, just 20k words of very obvious Tower Defense basics with pictures.

I'd like to change this review at some point, because it's got the makings of a good game, but it's just not there yet, in my opinion. There will be people who have no problem rerolling 50 times for a perfect start and with just enough of that "I can see the Matrix" vibe to do some crazy stuff, and I'm positive they're going to love it, but I think the average player will simply find it frustrating after a few games. Maybe it's just not for the casual gamers- and if it isn't, I hope some people read this and decide to wait on it. Maybe I'll be able to come back when the game is more balanced and change this.

This game while fun, is also absolutely terribly balanced.

Once you start getting into the higher difficulties the game starts to show it's massive flaws, ones that honestly just ruin the game and any fun you could have playing it. Does not help that the end game is just making the worst mode, even more terrible to play.

Don't get me wrong, behind some stupid decisions there is a enjoyable game to play on the 1-3 difficulties. The big issue comes in when you play with 4 and the challenge mode. You can most likely handle yourself through the waves for the most part but eventually you will start getting more special spawns than any combination of turrets can help you deal with at that point. For one reason mainly and that is that the basic towers are absolute shit for their cost. Upgraded? any tower is good. My gripe comes with the power of un-upgraded towers, you may as well not use anything below T2 this way. This is a problem when you have 4 lanes to defend since you hemorrhage money all the time trying to maximize your defenses but ultimately can't since the early game you have little to no generation for either resources or basic tower cards you can use.

Best example I can give is the first handful of towers you can afford to put down early in the game and why it's an issue.
Mirador: 200 gold, can be reduced. Upgrades are pretty shit, basically works as a HQ buffer/repairer.
Bunker: 200 gold. Great tower when upgraded, waste un-upgraded. But your bread and butter when you have second level upgrades which costs 400 extra gold base.
Mortar: 100 gold. It's... okay, it can be good in a lot of situations but generally they are not worth the little gold they cost because positioning them to be effective is difficult, especially with how they target, they go for the one furthest away from them, sounds good right? Except that could mean they ignore a cluster and shoot open ground on a fast moving enemy that is further from the mortar, which means it can do nothing an entire wave simply cause the target priority is bad.
Warwolf: Great tower all around, cheap first upgrade makes it a lot better for 150 gold. No downsides to this tower aside from upgrade costs being fairly steep for the early game where this tower is the best.


There are some others like the Puma and the Imperial barracks etc. But the main issue with all of these towers is the early game cost, and the fact that you just have to get lucky and find them in the random draw. Now mind you there is no Banish, no Re-roll, no Lock. You get 3-4 random cards after a wave and you best hope it has something useful to you or you can get rolled simply because you are not getting anything that can actually help you with no way to help yourself get the towers you need.

So all of that in mind, you now need to deal with how little gold you get a round. Base is +100 gold, plus some change for killing enemies and other factors. Most of your resource generation is entirely based on luck from Neutral buildings, if you get the right ones your run can be smooth, get nothing or bad ones? Your run is probably over pretty quickly from resource saturation.

Doesn't help the only resource you can use to re-roll the terrain is also very rare among towers and hard to find in neutral buildings so you can end up in a game where you only get 3-6 terrain re-rolls for a full 35 wave game. While not the end of the world this game has a massive preference for giving you the worst piece which is a 4 way entry. It is absolutely skewed and no one can convince me other wise. 

I could get into the factions and why they suck as well, mainly boiling down to their early game and endgame towers.
Green just got crapped on for real.





All in all if the devs do some rework on the power and cost of certain towers the game would be more fun at the "end game" part of the game. But as it is now, it's a lot more fun to play on 1-3 entries, since a 2 of the factions always have terrible starts on 4 entries.

This game has excellent content. The production value is high, the art is lovely, and the concepts are pretty interesting. I enjoyed it.

So why can't I recommend it? Well, it's extremely poorly balanced, and gets worse the higher you go with it. Insert queue of fedora-tipping non-neurotypical keyboard warriors to rush in and defend the game with their "trololololol u just suk git gud".

It's true, though. Having played it, there are frustrating jumps in difficulty at a variety of points, variable depending on the difficulty you've set. In fairness, they've added a number of modifiers to the game, and one of them specifically scales things based on the number of single paths to the fortress. Realistically, it's not enough for the average player, and the modifiers aren't communicated particularly well.

In fact, a lot of things aren't communicated well, and it seems like that's actually a design choice. For example, they do have a setting to show tower stats- it's off by default. More than that, when it's on, you need to hover over specific weapons on a tower in order to see what's going on with the stats, and even then, it doesn't feel particularly easy to read or understand, and it's difficult to know exactly how the modifiers are playing out.

The balance, though, feels way off. One second you're doing fine, and the next, the escalation has become so severe that you simply get crushed. And not "Ah man, I let a few through", I mean going from leaking a couple, to leaking dozens.

It lacks a lot of polish and features from the genre, and that makes it difficult to make decisions. For example, you begin to really notice the lack of a way to track the enemies numbers and types when you're struggling to cover multiple points of entry. To make that worse, you don't know how that's going to do. One minute, you're building a side that's threatening to overrun you- the next, suddenly you get very little traffic on that side, and the side you were neglecting to build up because you couldn't afford to, suddenly gets massive waves.

The more you play and the higher your difficulty, the more it narrows your strategies that are realistically available. Most of the choices you get in the game don't really feel like choices, because there are clear winners. (This isn't always the case, but it is a lot of the time, for a lot of your choices).

I did check out a couple guides that were trying to teach people things they were missing when they decided the game was too hard- very disappointed. They didn't teach anything out of the ordinary, just 20k words of very obvious Tower Defense basics with pictures.

I'd like to change this review at some point, because it's got the makings of a good game, but it's just not there yet, in my opinion. There will be people who have no problem rerolling 50 times for a perfect start and with just enough of that "I can see the Matrix" vibe to do some crazy stuff, and I'm positive they're going to love it, but I think the average player will simply find it frustrating after a few games. Maybe it's just not for the casual gamers- and if it isn't, I hope some people read this and decide to wait on it. Maybe I'll be able to come back when the game is more balanced and change this.

Mirador: 200 gold, can be reduced. Upgrades are pretty shit, basically works as a HQ buffer/repairer.

This game has excellent content. The production value is high, the art is lovely, and the concepts are pretty interesting. I enjoyed it.

So why can't I recommend it? Well, it's extremely poorly balanced, and gets worse the higher you go with it. Insert queue of fedora-tipping non-neurotypical keyboard warriors to rush in and defend the game with their "trololololol u just suk git gud".

It's true, though. Having played it, there are frustrating jumps in difficulty at a variety of points, variable depending on the difficulty you've set. In fairness, they've added a number of modifiers to the game, and one of them specifically scales things based on the number of single paths to the fortress. Realistically, it's not enough for the average player, and the modifiers aren't communicated particularly well.

In fact, a lot of things aren't communicated well, and it seems like that's actually a design choice. For example, they do have a setting to show tower stats- it's off by default. More than that, when it's on, you need to hover over specific weapons on a tower in order to see what's going on with the stats, and even then, it doesn't feel particularly easy to read or understand, and it's difficult to know exactly how the modifiers are playing out.

The balance, though, feels way off. One second you're doing fine, and the next, the escalation has become so severe that you simply get crushed. And not "Ah man, I let a few through", I mean going from leaking a couple, to leaking dozens.

It lacks a lot of polish and features from the genre, and that makes it difficult to make decisions. For example, you begin to really notice the lack of a way to track the enemies numbers and types when you're struggling to cover multiple points of entry. To make that worse, you don't know how that's going to do. One minute, you're building a side that's threatening to overrun you- the next, suddenly you get very little traffic on that side, and the side you were neglecting to build up because you couldn't afford to, suddenly gets massive waves.

The more you play and the higher your difficulty, the more it narrows your strategies that are realistically available. Most of the choices you get in the game don't really feel like choices, because there are clear winners. (This isn't always the case, but it is a lot of the time, for a lot of your choices).

I did check out a couple guides that were trying to teach people things they were missing when they decided the game was too hard- very disappointed. They didn't teach anything out of the ordinary, just 20k words of very obvious Tower Defense basics with pictures.

I'd like to change this review at some point, because it's got the makings of a good game, but it's just not there yet, in my opinion. There will be people who have no problem rerolling 50 times for a perfect start and with just enough of that "I can see the Matrix" vibe to do some crazy stuff, and I'm positive they're going to love it, but I think the average player will simply find it frustrating after a few games. Maybe it's just not for the casual gamers- and if it isn't, I hope some people read this and decide to wait on it. Maybe I'll be able to come back when the game is more balanced and change this.

My gripe comes with the power of un-upgraded towers, you may as well not use anything below T2 this way. This is a problem when you have 4 lanes to defend since you hemorrhage money all the time trying to maximize your defenses but ultimately can't since the early game you have little to no generation for either resources or basic tower cards you can use.

Best example I can give is the first handful of towers you can afford to put down early in the game and why it's an issue.
Mirador: 200 gold, can be reduced. Upgrades are pretty shit, basically works as a HQ buffer/repairer.
Bunker: 200 gold. Great tower when upgraded, waste un-upgraded. But your bread and butter when you have second level upgrades which costs 400 extra gold base.
Mortar: 100 gold. Warwolf: Great tower all around, cheap first upgrade makes it a lot better for 150 gold. No downsides to this tower aside from upgrade costs being fairly steep for the early game where this tower is the best.


There are some others like the Puma and the Imperial barracks etc. But the main issue with all of these towers is the early game cost, and the fact that you just have to get lucky and find them in the random draw. Now mind you there is no Banish, no Re-roll, no Lock. You get 3-4 random cards after a wave and you best hope it has something useful to you or you can get rolled simply because you are not getting anything that can actually help you with no way to help yourself get the towers you need.

So all of that in mind, you now need to deal with how little gold you get a round. Base is +100 gold, plus some change for killing enemies and other factors. Most of your resource generation is entirely based on luck from Neutral buildings, if you get the right ones your run can be smooth, get nothing or bad ones? Your run is probably over pretty quickly from resource saturation.

This game has excellent content. The production value is high, the art is lovely, and the concepts are pretty interesting. I enjoyed it.

So why can't I recommend it? Well, it's extremely poorly balanced, and gets worse the higher you go with it. Insert queue of fedora-tipping non-neurotypical keyboard warriors to rush in and defend the game with their "trololololol u just suk git gud".

It's true, though. Having played it, there are frustrating jumps in difficulty at a variety of points, variable depending on the difficulty you've set. In fairness, they've added a number of modifiers to the game, and one of them specifically scales things based on the number of single paths to the fortress. Realistically, it's not enough for the average player, and the modifiers aren't communicated particularly well.

In fact, a lot of things aren't communicated well, and it seems like that's actually a design choice. For example, they do have a setting to show tower stats- it's off by default. More than that, when it's on, you need to hover over specific weapons on a tower in order to see what's going on with the stats, and even then, it doesn't feel particularly easy to read or understand, and it's difficult to know exactly how the modifiers are playing out.

The balance, though, feels way off. One second you're doing fine, and the next, the escalation has become so severe that you simply get crushed. And not "Ah man, I let a few through", I mean going from leaking a couple, to leaking dozens.

It lacks a lot of polish and features from the genre, and that makes it difficult to make decisions. For example, you begin to really notice the lack of a way to track the enemies numbers and types when you're struggling to cover multiple points of entry. To make that worse, you don't know how that's going to do. One minute, you're building a side that's threatening to overrun you- the next, suddenly you get very little traffic on that side, and the side you were neglecting to build up because you couldn't afford to, suddenly gets massive waves.

The more you play and the higher your difficulty, the more it narrows your strategies that are realistically available. Most of the choices you get in the game don't really feel like choices, because there are clear winners. (This isn't always the case, but it is a lot of the time, for a lot of your choices).

I did check out a couple guides that were trying to teach people things they were missing when they decided the game was too hard- very disappointed. They didn't teach anything out of the ordinary, just 20k words of very obvious Tower Defense basics with pictures.

I'd like to change this review at some point, because it's got the makings of a good game, but it's just not there yet, in my opinion. There will be people who have no problem rerolling 50 times for a perfect start and with just enough of that "I can see the Matrix" vibe to do some crazy stuff, and I'm positive they're going to love it, but I think the average player will simply find it frustrating after a few games. Maybe it's just not for the casual gamers- and if it isn't, I hope some people read this and decide to wait on it. Maybe I'll be able to come back when the game is more balanced and change this.

This game while fun, is also absolutely terribly balanced.

Once you start getting into the higher difficulties the game starts to show it's massive flaws, ones that honestly just ruin the game and any fun you could have playing it. Does not help that the end game is just making the worst mode, even more terrible to play.

Don't get me wrong, behind some stupid decisions there is a enjoyable game to play on the 1-3 difficulties. The big issue comes in when you play with 4 and the challenge mode. You can most likely handle yourself through the waves for the most part but eventually you will start getting more special spawns than any combination of turrets can help you deal with at that point. For one reason mainly and that is that the basic towers are absolute shit for their cost. Upgraded? any tower is good. My gripe comes with the power of un-upgraded towers, you may as well not use anything below T2 this way. This is a problem when you have 4 lanes to defend since you hemorrhage money all the time trying to maximize your defenses but ultimately can't since the early game you have little to no generation for either resources or basic tower cards you can use.

Best example I can give is the first handful of towers you can afford to put down early in the game and why it's an issue.
Mirador: 200 gold, can be reduced. Upgrades are pretty shit, basically works as a HQ buffer/repairer.
Bunker: 200 gold. Great tower when upgraded, waste un-upgraded. But your bread and butter when you have second level upgrades which costs 400 extra gold base.
Mortar: 100 gold. It's... okay, it can be good in a lot of situations but generally they are not worth the little gold they cost because positioning them to be effective is difficult, especially with how they target, they go for the one furthest away from them, sounds good right? Except that could mean they ignore a cluster and shoot open ground on a fast moving enemy that is further from the mortar, which means it can do nothing an entire wave simply cause the target priority is bad.
Warwolf: Great tower all around, cheap first upgrade makes it a lot better for 150 gold. No downsides to this tower aside from upgrade costs being fairly steep for the early game where this tower is the best.


There are some others like the Puma and the Imperial barracks etc. But the main issue with all of these towers is the early game cost, and the fact that you just have to get lucky and find them in the random draw. Now mind you there is no Banish, no Re-roll, no Lock. You get 3-4 random cards after a wave and you best hope it has something useful to you or you can get rolled simply because you are not getting anything that can actually help you with no way to help yourself get the towers you need.

So all of that in mind, you now need to deal with how little gold you get a round. Base is +100 gold, plus some change for killing enemies and other factors. Most of your resource generation is entirely based on luck from Neutral buildings, if you get the right ones your run can be smooth, get nothing or bad ones? Your run is probably over pretty quickly from resource saturation.

Doesn't help the only resource you can use to re-roll the terrain is also very rare among towers and hard to find in neutral buildings so you can end up in a game where you only get 3-6 terrain re-rolls for a full 35 wave game. While not the end of the world this game has a massive preference for giving you the worst piece which is a 4 way entry. It is absolutely skewed and no one can convince me other wise.
